definitions: apply a lubricant to reduce friction between moving parts or surfaces
examples: The mechanic will lube your car engine during regular service
Remember to lube the bike chain before your long ride

definitions: carry or drag something heavy with great effort and difficulty
examples: She had to lug her heavy suitcase up three flights
The workers lugged boxes from the truck all morning

definitions: ride downhill on a small sled while lying face up feet first
examples: Athletes luge down the ice track at incredible speeds
She learned to luge during her winter vacation in Switzerland

definitions: soothe or cause to rest by gentle sounds or movements
cause someone to feel deceptively secure before something bad happens
examples: The mother sang softly to lull her baby to sleep
Ocean waves lulled the vacationers into peaceful afternoon naps
The enemy's retreat was meant to lull us into complacency
Don't let their friendly manner lull you into trusting them

definitions: move in a slow heavy awkward way typically making noise
examples: The bear lumbered through the forest looking for food
Heavy trucks lumber along the mountain road every morning

definitions: put together in a single group without making distinctions
form or cause to form into a compact mass or lumps
examples: Don't lump all teenagers together when discussing behavior problems
The report lumps several unrelated expenses into one category
The gravy will lump if you add flour too quickly
Cold oatmeal tends to lump together in the pot overnight

definitions: make a sudden forward thrust of the body typically to attack
examples: The fencer lunged at her opponent with perfect timing
The dog lunged forward trying to catch the flying disc

definitions: make an abrupt unsteady uncontrolled movement or series of movements
examples: The bus lurched forward when the driver hit the gas
He lurched across the room after spinning around too fast

definitions: tempt someone to do something or go somewhere by offering pleasure
examples: Bright window displays lure shoppers into expensive stores downtown
The company lured talented workers with high salaries and benefits

definitions: have a very strong sexual desire or powerful craving for something
examples: Medieval kings often lusted after power and territorial expansion
The collector lusted for the rare painting at the auction

definitions: kill someone especially by hanging for an alleged offense without legal trial
examples: Angry mobs would lynch suspected criminals in lawless frontier towns
The peaceful protesters opposed those who wanted to lynch the accused

definitions: write the words for a song or express emotions in poetic form
examples: She lyrics all her own songs for the band performances
The poet lyrics his deepest feelings about love and loss

definitions: make someone extremely angry or drive them to the point of rage
examples: Traffic jams during rush hour madden even patient commuters daily
His constant interruptions began to madden everyone at the meeting

definitions: color fabric or material using red dye from the madder plant root
examples: Traditional craftspeople madder wool to create beautiful red textiles
Artists madder their canvases to achieve deep crimson background colors

definitions: make something appear larger than it is especially with a lens
make something seem greater or more important than it really is
examples: Scientists magnify cells to study their structure under microscopes
This lens can magnify objects up to one thousand times
The media tends to magnify small problems into major crises
Don't magnify your mistakes by dwelling on them too long

definitions: inject a drug directly into a major vein for immediate effect
examples: Drug users who mainline substances face serious health risks daily
The documentary showed how addicts mainline heroin in abandoned buildings

definitions: fail to function normally or stop working properly as intended
examples: The elevator malfunctioned and trapped people between floors yesterday
Computer systems malfunction when viruses corrupt their operating files

definitions: speak about someone in a spitefully critical way to damage reputation
examples: Political opponents often malign each other during election campaigns
The gossip columnist would malign celebrities to sell more magazines

definitions: convert grain into malt by soaking germinating and drying for brewing
examples: Breweries malt barley to create the base for beer production
Traditional methods malt grain slowly over several days for quality

definitions: perform a ballroom dance of Cuban origin with hip movements and quick steps
examples: The couple learned to mambo during their Caribbean vacation cruise
Dance instructors teach students how to mambo with proper rhythm

definitions: move skillfully or carefully in a confined space or difficult situation
carefully guide a situation to achieve a desired outcome through planning
examples: The captain had to maneuver the ship through narrow harbor channels
Drivers maneuver their cars into tight parallel parking spaces downtown
Politicians maneuver behind the scenes to gain support for bills
She maneuvered the conversation away from uncomfortable personal topics

definitions: display or show a quality or feeling by one's acts or appearance
examples: His anxiety manifests through nervous habits like nail biting
The disease first manifests with mild flu-like symptoms

definitions: make copies of something especially documents using carbon paper or similar methods
examples: Secretaries would manifold important memos before email existed
The office manifolds receipts to keep records for multiple departments

definitions: move skillfully or carefully especially in tight spaces or difficult situations
carefully guide events or situations to achieve desired outcomes through planning
examples: Fighter pilots manoeuvre their jets through complex aerial formations
The driver had to manoeuvre around fallen trees after the storm
Diplomats manoeuvre negotiations to reach peaceful agreements between nations
She manoeuvred her way to the top through strategic career moves

definitions: cover envelop or disguise something like a cloak covers the body
examples: Fresh snow mantles the mountain peaks every winter morning
Darkness mantled the forest as the sun set behind hills

definitions: make goods or products on a large scale using machinery in factories
invent or fabricate evidence or stories that are not true
examples: The company manufactures computer chips for smartphones and tablets
This factory manufactures over ten thousand cars every month
The witness was caught trying to manufacture an alibi story
Some tabloids manufacture scandals to increase their sales numbers

definitions: apply animal dung to land to make soil more fertile for growing
examples: Farmers manure their fields every spring before planting crops
Gardeners manure vegetable plots to improve soil quality naturally

definitions: impair the appearance of something by damaging or marking its surface
examples: Scratches from keys mar the surface of the antique table
Rain threatened to mar the outdoor wedding ceremony yesterday

definitions: stain or streak something to look like variegated marble stone patterns
examples: Bakers marble cake batter to create swirled chocolate vanilla designs
Artists marble paper by floating paint on water surface

definitions: leave someone trapped and isolated in an inaccessible place without help
examples: The storm marooned tourists on the island for three days
Pirates would maroon sailors on deserted islands as punishment

definitions: arrange or assemble a group of people especially soldiers in order
bring together and organize ideas facts or resources for a purpose
examples: The general marshaled his troops before the dawn attack began
Security officers marshal crowds at large concerts for safety
She marshaled all the evidence to support her legal case
Writers marshal their thoughts before starting a new chapter

definitions: kill someone because of their religious or political beliefs as persecution
examples: Throughout history rulers have martyred those who opposed their authority
The regime martyred peaceful protesters who demanded democratic reforms

definitions: be filled with wonder or astonishment at something remarkable or unexpected
examples: Tourists marvel at the ancient pyramids in Egypt every year
Children marvel at fireworks lighting up the night sky

definitions: reduce something to a soft pulpy mass by crushing or beating
examples: Chefs mash potatoes with butter and cream for dinner
The machine mashes apples to make fresh cider every fall

definitions: pretend to be someone or something one is not to deceive others
examples: The spy masqueraded as a diplomat to gather secret information
Some companies masquerade cheap products as luxury brands online

definitions: deliberately and violently kill a large number of people especially helpless ones
examples: Invading armies would massacre entire villages during medieval wars
The documentary exposed how soldiers massacred innocent civilians

definitions: rub and knead muscles and joints to relieve tension or pain
alter facts or figures to make them appear more favorable than reality
examples: Physical therapists massage injured muscles to promote healing
She massages her temples when she gets stress headaches
Companies sometimes massage their financial data before quarterly reports
Politicians massage statistics to support their campaign promises

definitions: plan and direct a complex scheme or enterprise especially a criminal one
examples: Criminal bosses mastermind elaborate heists from behind the scenes
She masterminded the company merger that doubled their market share

definitions: tangle hair fur or fibers into a thick tangled mass
examples: Wet fur mats easily if you don't brush it regularly
The child's hair matted after playing outside all day

definitions: become actual fact or happen after being planned possible or expected
examples: Her dreams of becoming a doctor finally materialised after years
The promised funding never materialised despite repeated government assurances

definitions: become actual fact or happen after being planned expected or promised
appear in bodily form from nowhere as if by magic
examples: The new jobs promised by politicians failed to materialize
Their vacation plans materialized after months of saving money
Ghosts supposedly materialize in the haunted house at midnight
The magician made a rabbit materialize from an empty hat

definitions: give a dull or non-reflective finish to a surface or material
examples: Photographers matte their prints to reduce glare under gallery lights
The designer chose to matte the metal surface for aesthetic reasons

definitions: become fully developed physically emotionally or mentally over time
reach the time when a financial obligation becomes due for payment
examples: Fine wines mature in oak barrels for several years
Children mature at different rates during their teenage years
The bonds will mature in ten years with full interest
Your investment account matures next month for withdrawal

definitions: attack and injure someone by tearing at them roughly with hands or claws
examples: The bear mauled the hiker who ventured too close
Guard dogs might maul intruders who enter the property illegally

definitions: talk in a rambling manner without making much sense or clear point
examples: Grandfather tends to maunder about his childhood during family dinners
The professor maundered through the lecture confusing all the students

definitions: make as large or great as possible to reach the highest amount
examples: Smart investors maximise their returns by diversifying their portfolios
The factory maximises production by running three shifts every day

definitions: make as large or great as possible to achieve the fullest potential
examples: Companies try to maximize profits while minimizing operational costs
Athletes train hard to maximize their performance during competitions

definitions: follow a winding course or wander aimlessly without urgent destination or purpose
examples: The river meanders through the valley creating beautiful natural curves
Tourists meander through the old town exploring shops and cafes

definitions: interfere in something that is not one's concern often causing problems
examples: Neighbors shouldn't meddle in each other's personal family matters
Parents who meddle too much may damage relationships with adult children

definitions: intervene between parties in a dispute to help them reach an agreement
examples: Professional counselors mediate between divorcing couples over custody issues
The United Nations often mediates conflicts between warring nations
